verdict.summary: NoSuchBeanDefinitionException is thrown when Spring cannot find a bean definition matching the requested type or name. This typically means the class is not annotated as a Spring component, is not in a scanned package, or the configuration is missing.

dead_ends.action: Creating the bean manually with 'new' instead of letting Spring manage it
dead_ends.why_fails: Manually instantiating a Spring-managed class bypasses dependency injection entirely. The new instance will not have its @Autowired fields injected, @Transactional proxies will not be created, and AOP aspects will not apply. This creates a partially initialized object that fails in subtle ways.

dead_ends.action: Adding @Component to a class in a package that is not covered by @ComponentScan
dead_ends.why_fails: Spring only scans packages explicitly listed in @ComponentScan or sub-packages of the @SpringBootApplication class. Adding @Component to a class outside the scan path has no effect â€” Spring never sees the annotation.

workarounds.action: Ensure the class is annotated with @Component, @Service, @Repository, or @Controller and is within a package covered by component scanning
workarounds.how: 1. Verify the class has a Spring stereotype annotation (@Component, @Service, @Repository, @Controller, or @Configuration). 2. Check that the class's package is a sub-package of your @SpringBootApplication class's package. 3. If the class is in a different package tree, add it explicitly: @ComponentScan(basePackages = {'com.main', 'com.other'}). 4. For third-party classes, create a @Bean method in a @Configuration class to register them.

workarounds.action: Use @Bean method in a @Configuration class to explicitly define the bean when automatic scanning is not appropriate
workarounds.how: 1. Create a @Configuration class. 2. Add a @Bean method that returns the instance: @Bean public MyService myService() { return new MyServiceImpl(); }. 3. This is the correct approach for third-party classes, conditional beans (@ConditionalOnProperty), and beans requiring complex initialization. 4. For multiple implementations of the same interface, use @Qualifier or @Primary to disambiguate.

leads_to.condition: when adding the missing bean creates a circular reference with another bean
when multiple beans of the same type exist and Spring cannot choose between them

preceded_by.condition: when the class providing the bean is missing from the classpath
when a dependency exclusion removes the library containing the bean

frequently_confused_with.distinction: NoSuchBeanDefinitionException means no bean of the required type exists at all; UnsatisfiedDependencyException means a bean was found but its own dependencies could not be satisfied
